Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. The movie is divided into two parts: “Early Years” depicts his adolescence up until his giving up the world (1889-1938). It shows how exposed he was to various religions from an early age which strongly influenced him afterwards. It also chronicles his business life that has never been written about before.<|end_of_text|>

Well,I am a dancer so automatically I liked this film. The only thing I didn't like was they didn't have much dancing as I thought there would be, replacing more dialogue. There were some good fight moves in the film - you have to remember that it is an old film, 50 years old and times were different then. As another reviewer said, recent films are always compared with other modern films so should be free of that idea whilst viewing a film such as

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. Some people may think that there was gratuitous nudity throughout the film because there were mostly topless women being stared at by a couple of horny young men. But these scenes actually help to advance the plot.
There are two good performances in the movie and they come from Coluche and Xavier DeGuilly

If you are a fan of Zorro, Indiana Jones, or action in general this is a must-see. Directed by Republic's ace team of William Witney and John English and starring John Carroll & (authentic) Indian Chiefs with enough horses to choke em'.
For obvious reasons the storyline for this film was also used in The Lone Ranger.

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The film is based on Stephenie Meyer’s novel The Host.
